This award strives to conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. This includes The purpose of this project is to contribute to the conservation of the West African chimpanzee in Liberia by providing the next generation of Liberia’s natural resource managers with the tools to conduct both applied research and implement conservation programs to international standards. Design and implement a five-day residential training course covering field research methods; establish a small, accessible library of books, papers and reports relevant to the study and conservation of Liberian biodiversity; clear and map a trail system in the park for use by researchers, rangers and tourists; host national and international researchers to conduct applied research work; train a minimum of 5 community members in basic guiding skills; disseminate research findings through scientific publications, a dedicated website, local and national media and reports to the Forestry Development Agency; support an internship program where graduates from the University of Liberia and/or other partner institutions may be trained on applied conservation and ecological research; ensure Sapo NP bio-monitoring team members are fully equipped to continue to collect and analyze data on biological indicators for park management; and monitor and describe trends in chimpanzee distribution and density and relations between distribution and major identified threats on an annual basis..

description.narrative: The Ebola Virus Disease outbreak of 2014 - 2015 dramatically affected the progress that Liberia had made towards sustained development since the end of the 14-year civil war. While Liberia demonstrated strong leadership and partnership with the international community in successfully controlling the outbreak, the emergency highlighted institutional flaws, which undermined the population's trust in the Government of Liberia (GOL). Though the disease outbreak was largely brought under control by mid-2015, Liberia continues to suffer the social, economic, and health consequences of a national crisis that cut off access to basic services, slowed domestic trade, and curtailed international travel and commerce for an extended period. U.S. assistance in FY 2017 will continue to be an essential part of helping to bring the country back onto a sustainable development path. The United States will continue to promote a secure, stable Liberia with enhanced rule of law, broad-based economic development, and improved education and health systems.
